ssl.valid: Your application is secured, {info, property, firstName}. Nice work!
ssl.none: Hi {info, property, firstName}, please secure your application using an SSL configuration.

info.license: All information about the current license is displayed in here.

message.invalidCredentials: The entered username & password combination is invalid.
message.licenseUpload: Upload a license to be able to use this system.
message.logonError: Something went wrong during logon. Please try again later.
message.sslExpired: Your SSL certificate is expired. Upload a new certificate/key combination.
message.sslExpireSoon: Your SSL certificate will expire soon. Upload a new certificate/key combination.

info.security: This box provides an overview of the current security status with regards to SLL encryption. It's important to provide a trusted CA signed valid SSL certificate (and key) to enforce encryption on all communication with the application. Without SSL encryption, your application is more vulnerable to security threats. After uploading a valid certificate and key, change the API protocol and GUI protocol to HTTPS (both!) for optimal SSL encryption security.
info.certificate:
This box provides more information related to the uploaded SSL certificate. The most important aspects are:
  • Is your certificate signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA)?
  • Is your certificate still valid? This can be determined via the "expiry date". Make sure to upload a new valid SSL certificate and SSL key prior to expiration. After SSL certificate expiration, interaction with the application will be labeled as "insecure". In that case, services and browsers might refuse to communicate with the application.

upload.certificate: Each SSL configuration consists of a certificate and a key. Using the button in this box, you can upload a new certificate. The extension of the certificate must be ".crt".
upload.key: Each SSL configuration consists of a certificate and a key. Using the button in this box, you can upload a new key. The extension of the key must be ".key".

switchprotocol.api:
You can use the button in this box to change the protocol used by the API.

The following options are possible:
  • HTTP: Insecure
  • HTTPS: Secure
switchprotocol.gui:
You can use the button in this box to change the protocol used by the GUI.

The following options are possible:
  • HTTP: Insecure
  • HTTPS: Secure

validate.minChar: Must consist of at least {chars} characters
validate.lowerCaseOnly: Only lower case characters are allowed
validate.upperCaseOnly: Only upper case characters are allowed
validate.oneUpperCaseChar: Should contain a upper case letter
validate.notInPossibilities: Not a selection from the list of possibilities
validate.precisionNumber: Number should be rounded off with a precision of {precision}

help.intro: {right, select, own{Your own} isolated{Your team's} other{All}} active sessions are visualised here. An active session is established once a user logs in successfully.

properties.ip: The IP address of the user
properties.creation: The timestamp of the first successful log on of the session
properties.lastActive: The timestamp of the last usage of the session
properties.expired: The expiry status of the session
properties.token: The authentication token used for this session

info.title: active session: {item, property, user.firstName} {item, property, user.lastName} ({item, property, ip})

edit.title: edit active session: {item, property, user.firstName} {item, property, user.lastName} ({item, property, ip})

delete.title: are you sure you want to terminate this active session?

presentation.all: {item, property, user.firstName} {item, property, user.lastName} ({item, property, ip})
presentation.isolated: {item, property, user.firstName} {item, property, user.lastName} ({item, property, ip})

help.intro: "Actions" are the operations that can be performed on objects via the API. Common actions are: create, delete and edit.
An "Object" is a blob of data that represents a certain thing. This can be a physical or virtual element. Object data can be obtained via the API.

{right, select, own{Your own authentication method is} isolated{Your team members' authentication methods are} other{All authentication methods are}} visualised here. An authentication method is a method used to determine the validity of user credentials on log in. If the user credentials are valid, an active session will be created for that user. There's a "Default" authentication method, when selected the user credentials will be compared to the user information present in the database of the application. You can also make use of plugins providing additional (remote) authentication methods (e.g. the LDAP plugin).{right, select, own{} isolated{} other{ When making use of an authentication method provided by a plugin, we do recommend to keep at least one administrative user on the "Default" authentication method. To mitigate the risk of potential lock outs.}}

properties.name: The name of the authentication method
properties.plugin: The plugin providing the authentication method

info.title: authentication method: {item, property, name} ({item, property, plugin.name})

edit.title: edit authentication method: {item, property, name} ({item, property, plugin.name})

delete.title: are you sure you want to delete this authentication method?

help.intro: {right, select, own{Your own} isolated{Your team's} other{All}} files are visualised here. A file is an uploaded piece of content (e.g. picture, document).

properties.name: The file to upload
properties.creation: The timestamp of the file upload
properties.uploader: The user that uploaded the file
properties.size: The size of the file (in kB)

delete.title: are you sure you want to delete this file?

help.intro: {right, select, own{Your own} isolated{Your team's} other{All}} functions are visualised here. A function is a profession that is executed by a certain user.

delete.title: are you sure you want to delete this function?

help.intro: All plugins are visualised here. A plugin is an extension that can be used to add functionality to the system.

properties.name: The name of the plugin
properties.installed: The installation status of the plugin
properties.activated: The activation status of the plugin
properties.progress: The progress of the current plugin action
properties.default: A value that determines if the plugin is present on the system by default
properties.tags: Relevant keywords associated with this plugin
properties.required: The list of plugins that need to be installed first, before this plugin can be installed
properties.configPage: The reference to the web page used to configure the plugin
properties.logs: The log files of the plugin
properties.serviceStatus: The service status of the plugin

help.intro:
All rights are visualised here. A right is used to permit the execution of object operations to a certain group of users.
There are three types of access:
  • Own: Permits the group of users to perform the selected action on the selected 'owned' object. This means that the user should be related to this object in a direct manner.
    E.g.: A device owned by this user, the contact details of this user, etcetera...
  • Team: Permits the group of users to perform the selected action on the selected 'team' object. This means that the user should be related to this object via its team.
    E.g.: A device owned by the user's team, the contact details of a colleague in the same team, etcetera...
  • Full: Permits the group of users to perform the selected action on the selected object. This means that the user can perform the action on all objects. There is no limitation.
    E.g.: A device owned by another team, the contact details of a colleague in another team, etcetera...


When no team and function is selected, the right will apply to all users.

properties.apiObject: The object where the right provides access to
properties.apiAction: The action where the right provides access to
properties.team: The team where access is provided to
properties.function: The function where access is provided to
properties.own: Permits the group of users to perform the selected action on the selected 'owned' object
properties.isolated: Permits the group of users to perform the selected action on the selected 'team' object
properties.all: Permits the group of users to perform the selected action on the selected object without limitation

edit.title: edit right: [{item, property, apiObject.name} - {item, property, apiAction.name}]

delete.title: are you sure you want to delete this right?

help.intro: {right, select, own{Your own team is} isolated{Your own team is} other{All teams are}} visualised here. A team is a group where a certain user belongs to.

delete.title: are you sure you want to delete this team?

help.intro: All translations are visualised here. A translation is used to enable the GUI to work in different languages.

properties.translationFile: The name of the translation file that contains the contents of the translation
properties.locale: The locale that's used when selecting the translation
properties.enabled: A value that indicates if the translation is enabled for usage

presentation.isolated: {item, property, country} - {item, property, language} ({item, property, translationFile})
presentation.own: {item, property, country} - {item, property, language} ({item, property, translationFile})

help.intro:
All plugin option rights are visualised here. A plugin option right is used to allow modification of specific plugin parameters to a certain group of users.
When no team and function is selected, the plugin right will apply to all users.

properties.plugin: The plugin where the option belongs to
properties.apiAction: The action that can be performed by the user on the plugin option
properties.team: The team able to perform the action on the plugin option
properties.function: The function able to perform the action on the plugin option

info.title: plugin option right: [{item, property, plugin.name} - {item, property, option} ({item, property, group}) - {item, property, apiAction.name}]

edit.title: edit plugin option right: [{item, property, plugin.name} - {item, property, option} ({item, property, group}) - {item, property, apiAction.name}]

delete.title: are you sure you want to delete this plugin option right?

presentation.all: {item, property, plugin.name} - {item, property, option} ({item, property, group}) - {item, property, apiAction.name}
presentation.isolated: {item, property, plugin.name} - {item, property, option} ({item, property, group}) - {item, property, apiAction.name}
presentation.own: {item, property, plugin.name} - {item, property, option} ({item, property, group}) - {item, property, apiAction.name}

help.intro:
All plugin action rights are visualised here. A plugin action right is used to permit the execution of plugin actions to a certain group of users.
There are three types of access:
  • Own: Permits the group of users to perform the selected plugin action on 'owned' objects (if applicable). This means that the user should be related to this object in a direct manner.
  • Team: Permits the group of users to perform the selected plugin action on 'team' objects (if applicable). This means that the user should be related to this object via its team.
  • Full: Permits the group of users to perform the selected plugin action on any object (if applicable). This means that the user can perform the action on all objects. There is no limitation.


When no team and function is selected, the plugin right will apply to all users.

properties.plugin: The plugin where the right belongs to
properties.team: The team able to perform the action
properties.function: The function able to perform the action
properties.own: Permits the group of users to perform the selected plugin action on 'owned' objects (if applicable)
properties.isolated: Permits the group of users to perform the selected plugin action on 'team' objects (if applicable)
properties.all: Permits the group of users to perform the selected plugin action on any object (if applicable)

info.title: plugin action right: [{item, property, plugin.name} - {item, property, action}]

edit.title: edit plugin action right: [{item, property, plugin.name} - {item, property, action}]

delete.title: are you sure you want to delete this plugin action right?

expired.directions: Some pages within the application are not available when no valid license is provided. Please contact your administrator to obtain a new, valid license.

info.session-message: At the moment, there {amount, plural, one{is} other{are}} {amount} active {amount, plural, one{session} other{sessions}} making use of your account.

help.session: This box displays the total amount of active sessions registered to your account. You can view each of your active sessions in detail by clicking on the 'go-to-link' button (button with an arrow pointing at the right-top corner).
help.language:
This box displays your preferred language. The entire user interface will be displayed in this language.

The language you currently prefer is: "{language}".

The preferred language can be changed by clicking on the 'edit' button (button with a pencil).
help.timezone:
In this map, you can see your timezone. All time related data in this user interface is automatically converted to match your timezone. This timezone information is automatically detected. If this detected timezone is incorrect, please adapt the time settings on your local computer to match your actual timezone (and reload the page).

LEGEND:
  • Grey area: Covers all geographical zones that make use of your timezone.
  • Blue area: Covers your own geographical zone.
help.personal-details: In this box, all your personal details are displayed. If there is any false or outdated information displayed, you can modify it by clicking on the 'edit' button on the right of the detail (button with a pencil). If there's no 'edit' button present, please contact your system administrator to rectify the false information.
